what_it_measures_plain: Total cholesterol is the total amount of cholesterol in your blood (a mix of different types, including LDL and HDL).
how_to_read_results_plain: Lower is generally better for heart health. Your result is often interpreted together with LDL, HDL, triglycerides, and your overall risk factors.
if_high_may_mean_plain: Higher total cholesterol can be associated with a higher risk of heart and blood vessel problems over time.
if_low_may_mean_plain: Low total cholesterol is less common and is usually not a problem by itself; interpretation depends on the full clinical picture.
safe_next_step_plain: If your value is borderline or high, it’s reasonable to discuss it with a healthcare professional, especially if you have other risk factors.

what_it_measures_plain: LDL carries cholesterol through the bloodstream. Higher LDL can contribute to cholesterol buildup in blood vessel walls.
how_to_read_results_plain: Lower LDL is generally better. Target goals can differ based on your personal risk (for example, heart disease history).
if_high_may_mean_plain: Higher LDL may increase the risk of heart disease and stroke over time, especially when combined with other risk factors.
if_low_may_mean_plain: Lower LDL is usually favorable; your clinician may set individualized targets based on your health history.
safe_next_step_plain: If your LDL is elevated, a clinician can help interpret it in context and discuss heart-healthy lifestyle options.

sex_specific_ranges: Men: low <40, acceptable ≥40; Women: low <50, acceptable ≥50
what_it_measures_plain: HDL helps carry cholesterol away from the bloodstream to the liver for removal. Higher HDL is generally better.
how_to_read_results_plain: HDL is interpreted along with LDL, total cholesterol, and triglycerides. Sex-specific cutoffs are commonly used.
if_high_may_mean_plain: Higher HDL is often associated with lower heart disease risk, though it’s only one part of the overall picture.
if_low_may_mean_plain: Low HDL can be a risk marker for heart disease, especially if LDL or triglycerides are also high.
safe_next_step_plain: If HDL is low, discussing overall heart health (activity, diet, smoking status) with a clinician can be helpful.

what_it_measures_plain: Triglycerides are a type of fat in the blood. Levels can rise after eating and may be measured fasting for accuracy.
how_to_read_results_plain: Higher triglycerides can be linked with metabolic health and cardiovascular risk. Your clinician may interpret based on fasting status and other labs.
if_high_may_mean_plain: High triglycerides may be associated with higher cardiovascular risk; very high levels can be linked with pancreatitis risk.
if_low_may_mean_plain: Low triglycerides are usually not a concern and may reflect diet or overall metabolic status.
safe_next_step_plain: If triglycerides are high, reviewing fasting status and discussing lifestyle factors with a clinician is a common next step.
